Award.AwardTitle: Credibility and Use of Scientific and Technical Information in Science Policy Making: An Analysis of the Information Bases of the National Research Council's Committee Reports

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Policy makers and researchers often voice disappointment with the limited extent to which scientific and technical information is used in public policy decision-making. However, does the perception of the limited use of formal scientific and technical information (STI) accord with empirical reality? If STI is not the predominant information base in public policies, what other types of information are employed and how do these types of information compete with STI for inclusion in policy making? The project focuses on the use of STI in science policy deliberations, an area typically rife with relevant STI and advantaged by a STI user- and a STI producer-base practiced in the use of information. If the role of STI is limited in science policy, one would expect the role to be at least as limited in most other public policy domains. The present study examines the use of STI, and other information types, in National Research Council (NRC) reports of the National Academy of Science and the National Academy of Engineering. These reports seem especially useful for examining STI use. First, the National Academies apparatus is a quasi-public body charged by the U.S. Congress with providing advice about science and technology intensive policy issues. Thus, there is built-in policy demand for the reports produced by committees. Second, the NRC committee work is unusually information rich. The combination of the institutional prestige of the Academies, taken with the typically high level of prominence of NRC committee members, ensures a level of access to a wide variety of person-to-person and informal information resources.

The project's research approach entails developing a sample of 60 reports and subjecting them to intensive bibliometric analysis, determining the proportion of formal STI (defined as studies from peer-reviewed journals) to other type citations (e.g. gray literature, government documents, and expert testimony). The study considers a number of factors possibly related to the use of STI, including the composition of committees' panels, disciplinary backgrounds and the public visibility and controversy of the NRC study topics, as determined in content analyses of media coverage. Finally, the project considers the extent to which the use of STI affects the impacts of reports, determined by content analyses of media, including leading newspapers (e.g. column inches of coverage over time), number of page views on the Internet, citations from Scopus and Web of Science, and, especially, citations to the reports in actual laws and public policy documents.

Broader impacts. The project is expected to provide knowledge not only of the extent of STI use but the factors that affect its use in science policy making and the relationship of STI use to other information resources. Thus, findings have the potential to improve policy information and policy decisions. Study results will be used to develop a workshop conducted at national meetings of the AAAS. The workshop will bring together policy-makers and STEM researchers to discuss respective views about information needs for policy-making.

POR.DRECONTENT:
TITLE:  Credibility and Use of Scientific and Technical Information in Science Policy Making: An Analysis of the Information Bases of the National Research Council's Committee Reports

Barry Bozeman, Arizona State University

Jeffrey Wenger, RAND

Jan Youtie, Georgia Tech

This project examines how scientific and technical information is used in decision-making and what factors mediate this use. The overall objective has been to provide an evidence basis for understanding the extent to which peer-reviewed scientific and technical research is used in policy-making. In particular, the project studies the use of peer-reviewed research in reports of the National Academies, the policy-reporting arm formerly known as the National Research Council, and in turn, whether or not dissemination to policymakers is enhanced for reports with peer-reviewed research.

To address this objective, the project created a dataset of 589 policy reports of the National Academies. The dataset represents a careful merger of multiple information sources including individual policy reports in PDF format downloaded from the National Academies, digital indexes of journal articles and newspapers, report-level information about Congressional testimony briefings from the National Academies, and digital information about Congressional reports and activities. The dataset created from these multiple sources includes report characteristics such as page length, publication year, and share of citations to other National Academy reports; policy area; characteristics of the committee appointed to write the report such as sectoral affiliation of the committee chair, members, and reviewers; scientific and technical information characteristics of the report such as the percentage of references to journal articles or scientific conferences of which more than 120,000 of these references were classified using a semi-automated method; whether or not the report was explicitly authorized by Congress; and dissemination of the report through briefings, testimony or mentions in Congressional documents. It is publicly available at https://smartech.gatech.edu/handle/1853/56651. To supplement this empirical data, the project team conducted semi-structured interviews with 29 committee chairs involved in the writing of National Academy policy reports, 10 staff of the National Academies involved in the management of these reports; and two staff members of Congressional committees involved in the dissemination of these reports.

Intellectual Merit

The first study of the influence of peer reviewed research in National Academy reports used econometric modeling which considered characteristics of the National Academy reports, committee and reviewer sectoral characteristics, and whether or not the report was explicitly authorized by a member of Congress. The first stage model showed that peer reviewed research use was higher in more recent reports than earlier reports, in certain policy areas such as energy and environmental policy, in committees or reviewers with fewer private sector or governmental participants, and in reports requested by federal agencies rather than Congress. A second stage model found that, although nearly half of all NRC reports are explicitly conveyed to Congress, peer-reviewed research does not figure significantly in this conveyance, rather the length of the report and balance of the committee matters.

The second study based on 41 semi-structured elite interviews with National Academy executives and staff and committee members about use of peer reviewed research in reports issued by the National Academies. Findings show that the use of peer-reviewed reports varies according to the nature of the inquiry and the sponsor.  Peer-reviewed research tends to have modest effects on the likelihood that reports will be used in policy making or by the mass media.  More important factors include the timing of the report with respect to political agendas, the party requesting the report and the enacted roles of National Academy staff members and committee chairs.

Those interested in more detail may wish to consult the following publications (which are in the public domain and alos available from the authors). 

Youtie, J., Bozeman, B., Jabbehdari, S., & Kao, A. (2017). Credibility and use of scientific and technical information in policy making: An analysis of the information bases of the National Research Council’s committee reports. Research Policy, 46(1), 108-120.

 

B. Bozeman, J. Youtie, E. Fukumoto, M. Parker (in press) When is Science Used in Science Policy?  Examining the Importance of Scientific and Technical Information in National Research Council Reports, Review of Policy Research.  

Broader Impacts

Prior to this work, there were no empirical studies of National Academies policy reporting. This work developed an empirical basis, providing a framework for future analyses of the content of peer reviewed research in policy reports. Results were disseminated to key staff at the National Academies.

From the standpoint of human capital development, the data gathered in this project was employed to education several graduate students and has served for the dissertation research of Andrew Kao (who defended his dissertation in August 2018).
